data.title: The Fairly OddParents: The Movie
data.meta_description: Fairly OddParents: The Movie is a 2006 American-animated hand-drawn, action-adventure, musical comedy film produced by Nickelodeon Movies, Frederator Studios, and Paramount Pictures. It is based on the TV Series of the same name. The film is directed by Sarah Frost and Butch Hartman and will be...
data.text:
Fairly OddParents: The Movie is a 2006 American-animated hand-drawn, action-adventure, musical comedy film produced by Nickelodeon Movies, Frederator Studios, and Paramount Pictures. It is based on the TV Series of the same name. The film is directed by Sarah Frost and Butch Hartman and will be produced by Steve Marmel. Butch Hartman will serve as both the director and executive producer of the film. The film will be released in theaters on September 15, 2006.

The film features the same cast reprising their roles from the original series, including: Tara Strong, Carlos Alazraqui, Daran Norris, Susan Blakeslee, Jason Marsden, and Gary LeRoi Gray.

Plot[]

The movie follows 10-year old Timmy Turner who has two fairy godparents named, Cosmo and Wanda. One day, while in detention doing homework, he receives a strange letter that flew in from the window. The letter is from someone named D. Timmy thinks that it might be Denzel Crocker who wrote the letter, and is out to get him. Later, it turns out that Crocker actually wrote the letter as a way to trick Timmy into giving his fairies to him. Now that Crocker has got Cosmo and Wanda, he teams up with past villains to destroy the existence of fairies for good and take over planet Earth. Timmy has defeated Crocker without his fairies before. But now since Crocker teamed up with other villains and each has minion helpers, it makes this twice as hard as Timmy thinks.

Cast[]

Tara Strong as Timmy Turner, Britney Britney

Daran Norris as Cosmo, Mr. Turner, Jorgen Von Strangle, April Fool, Mr. Buxaplenty, Anti-Cosmo

Susanne Blakeslee as Wanda, Mrs. Turner, Mrs. Buxaplenty, Anti-Wanda

Grey DeLisle as Vicky, Tootie, Veronica, Principal Waxelplax

Chris Kirkpatrick as Chip Skylark

Jim Ward as Chet Ubetcha, Doug Dimmadome, Record Executive

Robert Costanzo as Easter Bunny

Carlos Alazraqui as Denzel Crocker, Sheldon Dinkleberg, Juandissimo Magnifico, Delores Day Crocker, Mayor of Dimmsdale, Chompy the Goat

Jane Carr as Mama Cosma

Rob Paulsen as Bucky McBadbat, Mark Chang, and King Gripullon

Laraine Newman as Queen Jipjorrulac

Tom Kenny as Cupid

Kevin Michael Richardson as Dark Laser

Butch Hartman as Bouncer, Dr. Rip Studwell

Dionne Quan as Trixie Tang

Faith Abrahams as Francis

Dee Bradley Baker as Sanjay, Elmer, Binky Abdul

Jason Marsden as Chester McBadbat

Gary Leroi Gray as A.J.

Story[]

Writing a story for the film was very difficult for the crew since the story had to have the original roots of the series. The idea of the story is to improve from the TV series. Butch Hartman was concerned since he wanted the story of the movie to be entertaining and appealing to audiences without losing charm the series had. Hartman then tried to find strongest writers as possible. He then re-signed Kevin Arrieta, Will Schifrin, Sindy Spackman, and Kevin Sullivan to start a fresh new story for the film. Butch Hartman also wrote the story for the film.

Production[]

Animation[]

The animation was to be animated like the older episodes in the series. All of the animation was done by Yeson Entertainment like the series. Butch Hartman described the animation as a tribute to the older episodes that were animated with digital ink and paint. Hartman also stated that he wanted the animation to stay true to the original series.

Backgrounds[]

All of the backgrounds in the film were given a different look to them. The backgrounds were colored and designed by the same palettes from the original series. with slightly new bright color tints to give it the more colorful and modern look.

Casting[]

Tara Strong announced that she will reprise her role as Timmy Turner. Daran Norris and Susan Blaskeslee will also return as their roles of Cosmo and Wanda, and Timmy's parents. The rest of the cast was confirmed.

Visual Effects[]

The Additional CG were done by Nickelodeon Digital Animation Studios in New York City, New York.

Post-Production[]

The post-production sound services were provided by Advantage Audio in Burbank, California. Robert Poole II, the sound effects editor from Bunsen Is A Beast!, The Buzz on Maggie, Danny Phantom, later episodes of The Fairly OddParents, Pig Goat Banana Cricket, Mickey Mouse (2013), Robot and Monster, T.U.F.F. Puppy, The Buzz on Maggie, Phineas and Ferb, The Looney Tunes Show, Pickle and Peanut, The Tom and Jerry Show, and other shows and movies including Winnie the Pooh: Springtime with Roo, Phineas and Ferb: The Movie, Phineas and Ferb the Movie: Across the 2nd Dimension, Phineas and Ferb: Star Wars (Star Destroyer's guns). Robert Duran, the sound designer from Atlantis: Milo's Return, Teamo Supremo, Tonka Town, New Looney Tunes/Wabbit: A Looney Tunes Production, later episodes of Recess, Â¡Mucha Lucha!, The Weekenders, later episodes of Johnny Test (Season 4-6), An All Dogs Christmas Carol

The post-production sound services were also provided by Skywalker Sound in Marin County, California. Randy Thom, Gary A. Rizzo and Michael Silvers, the Re-recording Mixers from The Incredibles, Randy Thom, the Sound Effects Editors from The Incredibles (The Omnidroid, Incredibile), Quest for Camelot, Gary Rydstrom, the supervising sound editor from the Star Wars prequel trilogy (pod racer engines, Naboo Starfighter's guns) Toy Story (Woody's toy string pulling, rocket exploding) and Toy Story 2 (Buzz Lightyear's rockets), Atlantis: The Lost Empire (exploding chasm), Tom Myers, the sound design from Cars, Ben Burtt, the sound editor from the first Star Wars movies (lightsaber clashes, carbon freeze chamber, X-wing and TIE fighter's guns, Death Star superlaser fire sequence, X-wing's proton torpedoes).

Music[]

Like in the original series, Guy Moon composes all of the score in the film. Moon stated that composing the music for a Fairly OddParents feature film was a challenge as he wanted the score to stay true to the style of Fairly OddParents and be appealing and full of emotion without wearing the audience out.
